Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts prepared by microwave heating for partial methanation coupling with water gas shift under low H2/CO conditions Xinxin Dong Baosheng Jin ⁎ Yiqing Sun Kun Shi Lei Yu Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education, School of Energy & Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory of Energy Thermal Conversion and Control of Ministry of Education School of Energy & Environment Southeast University Nanjing 210096 People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts were prepared by microwave and conventional heating separately, and tested for partial methanation coupling with water gas shift (WGS) of simulated biomass gas in a fixed bed reactor. A series of characterization techniques including N2 isothermal adsorption, XRD, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, SEM, TEM and XPS were employed to examine the physico-chemical properties of the catalysts. With the reaction condition of 350 °C, H2/CO = 0.8 and H2O/CO = 1, 82.6% CO conversion, 70.0% CH4 selectivity and 82.8% CO2 growth rate were obtained on the Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst, which indicated its excellent synergetic effect on partial methanation coupling with WGS. According to the characterization results, it was found that microwave heating was beneficial to increase the dispersion of Ni species in comparison with conventional heating and the addition of Re promoter elevated the catalytic performance from both structural and electronic aspects, which was proven by the lowered reduction temperature of β-type NiO and the intensified electron cloud density of active Ni atoms, respectively. In addition, the sequence of Re impregnation also had impact on the catalytic performance. Step impregnation prepared Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) exhibited larger turnover frequency (TOF) than co-impregnation prepared Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) in the H2/CO range of 0.6–1.0, owing to the larger electron cloud density and better anti-coking ability of the former catalyst. The 110-h lifetime test further demonstrated the potential of stable Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst in industrial application. Keywords Microwave heating Re promoter Bifunctional catalyst Methanation Water gas shift 1 Introduction The rapid development of urbanization in China has spontaneously urged an increasing demand for centralized energy supply [1–3]. Therefore, the gas supply is naturally endowed with considerable significance. At the present stage, urban gas is principally composed of coal gas generated from coal gasification and pipeline natural gas exploited from gas field. However, excess consumption of coal is disadvantageous to the total environment and pipeline natural gas is occasionally of high price due to market turbulence. Such drawbacks drive people to produce supplementary and/or alternative urban gas that is environmentally friendly and economically feasible. Biomass gas, one type of sustainable and recyclable energy manufactured by gasification of organic materials such as forestry and agricultural residues, could be highly promising as substitute or supplemental gas source for urban gas owing to the extensive existence of raw materials [4,5]. Hence, if fully utilized, the biomass gas would breed great economic and social benefit. Normally, biomass gas comprises CO, H2, CO2 and N2 as well as a small amount of water vapor. Nevertheless, on account of diverse biomass materials [6,7] and gasification agents such as air, H2O, O2 [8–11], the H2/CO ratio of obtained biomass gas varies to a great extent and particularly, biomass gas with low H2/CO ratio (H2/CO < 1) is rarely mentioned on its applications by reason of its relatively high perniciousness and low heating value. A traditionally effective way to avoid the above shortcomings is to reduce the CO content by water gas shift (WGS) (Eq. (1)) and synthesize CH4 by methanation (Eq. (2)). Through those two reactions, the content of noxious CO is reduced to safe value and in the meantime the heating value of biomass gas is improved due to the formation of CH4 (Lower Heating Value for CO: 12.64 MJ/Nm3, for CH4: 35.91 MJ/Nm3). (1) C O + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 Δ H 0 = - 40.6 k J / m o l (2) C O + 3 H 2 → C H 4 + H 2 O Δ H 0 = - 206.1 k J / m o l Conventionally, WGS reaction and methanation are carried out in separated reactors using specific catalysts and if necessary, such as in ammonia synthesis or natural gas production from coal, the two reaction units are merely in linear connection, which is uneconomical in equipment cost and inconvenient in operation. In our previous study [12], a novel idea concerning an integrated unit was proposed. The integrated unit was designed to compress methanation and WGS into one reactor and was applied for urban gas production from biomass gas with low H2/CO ratio. Above all, the core element of the integrated unit was the Ni-Mn bifunctional catalyst, which was proven to have favorable synergy effect to catalyze methanation and water gas shift simultaneously. As is well known, catalysts with satisfying performance generally encompass several elements including support, active component and indispensable promoter. Take the Ni-Mn bifunctional catalyst we have researched as example. Ni plus Mn act as active component and γ-Al2O3 plays the role of support. However, catalyst promoter, which is mainly employed to improve the activity and durability, is remained to be investigated. In this case, it is meaningful and necessary to study the effect of promoter on the Ni-Mn bifunctional catalyst. From the present research status, plenty of exposed literatures have reported the promotion effect of various additives into Ni-based catalyst. Kim et al. [13] probed the promotion effect of four precious metals involving Ru, Rh, Pt and Ir by the means of impregnation onto the Ni-MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and revealed that Ir metal had better promotion effect for CO selective methanation than the other three metals, primarily owing to its enhancement in reducibility and CO affinity. Zahra and his co-workers prepared samarium promoted Ni-SBA-15 catalysts by two-solvent impregnation method for dry reforming of methane and according to their research, the catalytic activity and stability was enhanced due to samarium promotion in the interaction of NiO particles with the support and dispersion of NiO species [14]. Moreover, promotion effect of alkali metals such as K on metal-carbon bond strength [15] and alkaline earth metals, for instance, Ca on CH4 selectivity [16] and Mg on mechanical and chemical property of Ni-based catalysts [17–19] were also investigated. Apart from the above-mentioned metal elements, nonmetal additives have also been studied. Kambolis et al. [20] discovered that boron had excellent performance in carbon resistance due to the effective prevention of carbon diffusion on Ni, resulting in the augmented stability for CO methanation. In spite of the broad range of researches, few investigations focus on the promotion effect of Re, which is a member of VIIB elements in the periodic table but plays an important role in the modern chemical industry. It was only infrequently reported that Re had outstanding promotion effect on Fisher-Tropsch synthesis [21,22] or on methanation reaction [23]. At the moment, the most pervasive way to heat catalyst precursors is conducted in the muffle furnace. Such conventional heating usually takes several hours which could cause unnecessary waste on energy. Besides, the lengthy heating process will induce the movement and aggregation of surface crystals, leading to a reduction in the dispersion of active components. Microwave heating, a novel technique to prepare catalysts, has recently attracted much attention and is shown to be promising for developing well-performed catalysts because of its unique heating characteristic. Compared to traditional heating way by external conduction or convection, microwave heating is internally generated [24], which causes fast and uniform heating. This phenomenon results in evenly distributed active components and promoter on the surface of the support [25,26] as well as mechanically enhanced pore structure [24]. Considering its multiple advantages and relatively few researches, it is worthwhile to apply this method in the preparation of Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts. The purpose of this work concentrated on the application of microwave heating to the simple and rapid preparation of Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts, along with comparing their performance with catalysts prepared by conventional heating. In addition, with the intention of discerning the influence of Re impregnation sequence on the performance of partial methanation coupling with WGS, Re-promoted Ni-Mn catalysts separately using step impregnation and co-impregnation method were correspondingly prepared. The catalysts were roundly characterized by N2 isothermal adsorption, XRD, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, SEM, TEM and XPS. Through above characterization and activity tests, the effect of microwave heating, Re promotion and its impregnation sequence were emphatically discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts supported by γ-Al2O3 granules were prepared using the step impregnation and co-impregnation method, respectively. The whole preparation process was elucidated in the following two sections. 2.1.1 Preparation by co-impregnation method The γ-Al2O3 support (Henan Chuangmei Environmental Protection Co., Ltd.) was firstly added to the aqueous solution containing an appropriate amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) and NH4ReO4 (Guangdong Wengjiang Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.). The heterogeneous mixture was then maintained in water bath at 60 °C for 12 h in order to disperse the Ni, Mn and Re species uniformly. The acquired precursors were dried at 110 °C in a drying oven and subsequently divided into two equal portions. The first part was calcined in a temperature programmed muffle furnace at 400 °C for 5 h to prepare catalyst by the conventional heating method. Resulting catalysts were denoted as Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MF). The second portion was subjected to microwave heating in a self-designed experimental apparatus as shown in Fig. 1 (introduced specifically in the S1 section of supplementary material). The correspondingly obtained catalysts were marked as Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV). For comparison, Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF) and Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) were prepared in the same manner. 2.1.2 Preparation by step impregnation method First of all, an equivalent amount of NH4ReO4 as mentioned above was dissolved in distilled water and followed by the addition of γ-Al2O3 support. Likewise, the mixture was kept in water bath at 60 °C for 12 h and dried at 110 °C. Then the catalyst precursors were split into two equal parts. The first part was firstly calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 5 h and followed by the mixing with the solution of Ni(NO3)2 and Mn(NO3)2. After the same impregnation and drying period, the products were once again calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 5 h. Resulting catalysts were denoted as Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MF). The second part was first subjected to microwave heating as mentioned above and subsequently mixed with the solution of Ni(NO3)2 and Mn(NO3)2. After the maintenance in water bath and drying, the precursors were second time transferred to microwave heating. The corresponding catalysts were marked as Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV). The nominal loading of nickel, manganese and/or rhenium in each of the acquired catalyst was devised as 15, 3 and/or 1 wt.%, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The actual metal loading in the obtained catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) for elemental analysis (Optima 8000, PerkinElmer, USA). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded with an Autosorb-iQ apparatus (Quantachrome, USA). Prior to N2 adsorption, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 100 °C for 5 h. The specific surface areas of the support and catalysts were calculated using BET method and the pore diameters as well as pore volumes were calculated on the basis of the standard BJH algorithm. XRD spectra were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (Xpert powder DY5030, PANalytical Co., Netherlands), operating with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154056 nm, 40 kV, 100 mA). The samples were scanned with Bragg’s angles ranging between 5° and 80° with a speed of 5°/min. The diameter (d) of the crystal was estimated from certain diffraction peak in XRD patterns using Debye-Scherrer equation shown in Eq. (3), where K is the Scherrer constant, taken as 0.89 and λ is the wavelength of X-ray, set as 1.54,056 Å. Letter B and θ are the measured half peak width and diffraction angle, respectively. (3) d = K λ B c o s θ The measurement of H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a chemisorption analyzer (Micrometrics Autochem II 2920) using the mixed reduction gas (10% H2/90% Ar). Prior to the H2-TPR experiment, typically 100 mg of the catalyst samples were preheated at 300 °C for 1 h under Ar flow to remove the adsorbed impurities. After cooling the reactor down to room temperature, the mixed reduction gas (40 mL/min) was introduced and the samples were reheated to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was performed on the same instrument as H2-TPR. Firstly, about 200 mg of the fresh catalyst samples were reduced in situ under H2 flow at 450 °C for 4 h and subsequently were cooled down to room temperature for H2 saturation. After the physically adsorbed H2 was removed by purging with Ar for 1 h, TPD of chemically adsorbed H2 was performed by ramping the temperature at 10 °C/min to 800 °C in Ar flow (30 mL/min). The desorbed H2 was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The dispersion of Ni was calculated based on the volume of chemisorbed H2 using the simplified Eq. (4) referring to the literature [27], where Vad (mL) is the volume of chemisorbed H2 in the H2-TPD measurement at standard temperature and pressure (STP) conditions; M is the molecular weight of Ni (58.69 g/mol); SF is the stoichiometric factor based on the assumption of adsorption stoichiometry H/Ni = 1:1; m is the mass of sample (g); P is weight fraction of Ni in the sample determined by ICP; Vm is the molar volume of H2 (22.4 L/mol) at STP and dr is the reduction degree of Ni calculated on the basis of H2-TPR. (4) D % = 100 × 2 × V a d × M × S F m × P × V m × d r The amount of carbon deposition was determined on a PerkinElmer thermogravimetry (TG) instrument. The catalyst samples were treated under 50 mL/min of air flow and the profiles were recorded from room temperature to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The TEM including HRTEM images were photographed using a JEOL JEM 2010 electron microscope. SEM was conducted on an S-4800 scanning electron microscope to observe the microscopic features of the samples. X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) analysis was conducted on a KRATOS XSAM800 spectroscopy analyzer with monochromatic Mg Kα radiation (1253.6 eV) as the excitation source. Binding energies were calibrated using C1s peak (284.6 eV) as reference. 2.3 Catalyst activity evaluation The evaluation of catalyst activity was carried out in a self-designed experimental apparatus [12]. Typically, 50 mL of the as-prepared catalysts with 2–3 mm of particle size were initially transferred to a fixed-bed reactor (φ57 mm × 3.5 mm × 1000 mm). Prior to reaction, the catalyst bed was heated from room temperature to 450 °C with a heating rate of 4 °C/min under a stream of pure N2 and then was subjected to pure H2 (GHSV: 1000 h−1) for 4 h to fully reduce nickel oxides to metallic Ni. After reduction, the catalyst bed was cooled below 250 °C under nitrogen and then simulated biomass gas with composition of 12% CO2, 8% N2 and 0.6–1.0 H2/CO (GHSV: 2000 h−1) was switched on as feed gas. A certain flow of steam (molar ratio H2O/CO = 1) was introduced to the reactor soon after the temperature increased. The reaction was performed under 0.1 MPa atmosphere in the temperature region of 300–400 °C with 25 °C of interval. The outlet production gas was cooled by a cold trap and processed through allochroic silicagel to remove the containing moisture. The gaseous products collected in air bag were subsequently separated and quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (GC2018, Shimadzu) which was equipped with a 2 m molecular sieve column and 3 m Porapak Q column. Helium was employed as carrier gas. The concentrations of H2, CO2, N2, CH4 and CO were analyzed by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) while C2H4 and C2H6 were analyzed by a flame ionization detector (FID). The temperature of TCD and FID were set to 100 and 250 °C, respectively. The conversion of CO (X CO), the selectivity of CH4 (S CH4) and the growth rate of CO2 (R CO2) were calculated using the following three expressions to define the overall catalytic activity and the degree of methanation and WGS, respectively, where F is the molar flow of the inlet and outlet species. (5) X C O ( % ) = ( F C O i n - F C O o u t ) / F C O i n × 100 (6) S C H 4 % = F C H 4 o u t / ( F C O i n + F C O 2 i n - F C O o u t - F C O 2 o u t ) × 100 (7) R C O 2 % = ( F C O 2 o u t - F C O 2 i n ) / F C O 2 i n × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microwave heating behavior The microwave heating curves of the catalyst precursors under 1.0 kW output power were plotted in Fig. 2 . As can be clearly seen, the curves display different patterns, which are closely related to the characteristics of catalyst materials. Generally, Re-Al2O3 and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 have larger average slopes in temperature rise than Ni-Mn/Al2O3 and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3, which indicates that incorporating Re first into γ-Al2O3 support by step impregnation can enhance the microwave absorption ability. This directly shortens the time for reaching 400 °C (specifically shown in region B). For Ni-Mn/Al2O3 and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 precursors that are both prepared by co-impregnation method, there is a platform starting at around 150 °C on the heating curves (region A in Fig. 2). This platform is mainly caused by the thermal balance between nitrate decomposition and microwave irradiation. However, such platform does not distinctly appear on the heating curves of Re-Al2O3 and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 and only small isothermal period for the above two samples can be observed, possibly owing to the enhancement in the thermal decomposition of nitrates due to Re first addition in the support. As the TG analysis in Fig. S1 proves, Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 precursor has lower decomposition temperature than Ni-Mn/Al2O3 and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 precursors. According to research literature [25], rapid microwave heating could form molecular hot spots that further induce effective dispersion of active components on the support surface, which is conducive to improve the catalyst activity. The enhancement in the dispersion of active components on the above catalysts will be verified in the following discussions. 3.2 Characterization analysis 3.2.1 Physico-chemical analysis The physical properties of the γ-Al2O3 support and as-prepared catalysts were evaluated by N2 isothermal absorption-desorption measurements (Fig. S2). The derived specific surface area and pore volume were compiled in Table 1 . As can be seen, the specific surface area and pore volume of the γ-Al2O3 support are listed as 241.46 m2/g and 0.39 cm3/g, respectively. After the loading of active Ni and Mn species as well as Re promoter, the catalysts display shrunk specific surface area and pore volume, suggesting the blockage of some micropores due to metal addition [28]. However, the specific surface area and pore volume of as-prepared catalysts are still amply large for the reactant gas contacting with active sites to proceed the catalytic reactions. Furthermore, according to ICP results in Table 1, Ni, Mn and Re are basically loaded on the support with the content of 15, 3 and 1 wt.%, respectively, indicating the feasibility of preparing catalysts by impregnation method. The minor error is caused by the transfer of solutions during the preparation and partially comes from the measuring instrument itself. 3.2.2 XRD analysis To investigate the crystalline phases of all the as-prepared catalysts as well as their corresponding reduced ones, powder XRD measurement was performed. The patterns were illustrated in Fig. 3 and all diffraction peaks were identified with PDF card files which were integrated in Jade6 software database. For as-prepared catalysts in Fig. 3A, all catalysts exhibit distinct diffraction patterns of γ-Al2O3 and NiO, which can be indicated from peaks at 2θ = 37.4, 45.8 and 67.3° (PDF#04-0880) and peaks at 2θ = 43.2 and 62.8° (PDF#47-1049), respectively. Interestingly, for those Re-promoted catalysts (b, c, e and f), diffraction peaks assigned to Re oxides cannot be observed possibly due to the detection limit of instrument or their high dispersion on the support [29]. Besides, several obvious difference in XRD patterns originated from preparation method can be clearly noticed. Firstly, the three catalysts prepared by microwave heating (a, b and c) all display diffraction peaks at 2θ = 14.3, 19.6 and 28.1° belonging to AlO(OH), which may be caused by strong vapor adsorption on the porous support (Al2O3 + H2O = 2AlO(OH)). Considering comparatively short microwave heating time in the preparation process (only 10 min), the produced AlO(OH) with small quantity cannot be decomposed completely but could be decreased as much as possible if microwave heating time was elongated (Fig. S3). This is also proven by disappeared diffraction peaks of AlO(OH) in the XRD patterns of the three catalysts prepared by conventional heating (d, e and f, calcined in muffle furnace for 5 h). Secondly, the NiO diffraction peaks of catalysts prepared by microwave heating are generally broader than catalysts prepared by conventional heating and NiO diffraction peaks at 2θ = 62.8° are even invisible, suggesting the positive effect of microwave on the enhancement of NiO dispersion. For the reduced catalysts in Fig. 3B, XRD patterns of all catalysts are similar with each other. Apart from typical diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 support, there peaks exist at 2θ = 44.5, 51.8 and 76.3°, which correspond to (111), (200) and (220) planes of Ni crystals, respectively. The Ni crystalline size of reduced catalysts were calculated according to Debye-Scherrer equation and were listed in Table 1. It can be seen that Ni crystalline size of Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 catalysts are smaller than Ni-Mn/Al2O3 catalyst. Moreover, the Ni crystalline size of catalysts prepared by microwave heating are generally smaller than catalysts prepared by conventional heating. Hence, it can be concluded that addition of Re species and adoption of microwave heating method can induce the formation of Ni crystals with small size. Interestingly, it seems that the Mn species show no prominent diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns of all reduced catalysts. One reason may be that the promotion effect of Re species in dispersion of Ni particles is also applicable to Mn species. In addition, the relatively low content of Mn species may also account for the absence of their diffraction peaks in XRD patterns [30,31]. 3.2.3 H2-TPR and H2-TPD analysis H2-TPR and H2-TPD patterns were collected in Fig. 4 A and B, respectively. The type of surface Ni species, their reducibility and the interaction between NiO and Al2O3 support can be clearly characterized by H2-TPR and presented in profiles [32]. In order to exclude the direct role of Re in the observed reduction peaks, the control experiment on the Re impregnated support was also conducted and the results were shown in Fig. S4. It can be carefully seen that both Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Re-Al2O3 (MF) display a subtle reduction peak at 315 °C, which is ascribed to the reduction of Re species. The contribution of Re reduction could be neglected in comparison with the prominent reduction peaks of NiO. Hence, the H2-TPR profiles in Fig. 4A can veritably characterize the status of reducible NiO. Basically, according to the reduction temperature, the reducible NiO in Fig. 4A can be generally divided into three regions: α, β and γ. The α-type NiO is attributed to free NiO species located on the surface of the Al2O3 support, which interact weakly or even have no interaction with the support [33]. The β-type NiO, usually consisting of β1 (Ni-rich phase) and β2 (Al-rich phase), represents highly dispersed crystal NiO species that have stronger interaction with the Al2O3 support than α-type NiO [34,35]. According to published literatures [36,37], from the perspective of the NiO location, the α-type and β-type NiO can also be recognized as Ni(II) in the outmost surface and subsurface of the support, respectively. The γ-type NiO is conventionally regarded as surface fixed nickel aluminate with spinel structure (NiAl2O4), which is difficult to be reduced under experimental condition. Through careful observation, some difference among the H2-TPR patterns of the six prepared catalysts could be observed. As can be seen in Fig. 4A, the reduction peaks of α- and β-type NiO in the catalysts prepared by microwave heating shift to lower temperature compared to the catalysts prepared by conventional heating, indicating microwave heating is favorable for the reduction of NiO species. Besides, the peak intensity of α-type NiO for microwave heating prepared catalysts is much larger than conventional heating prepared catalysts, possibly due to the partial transformation of β-and γ-type NiO into α-type NiO. It is considered that α-type NiO is beneficial to the low temperature methanation reaction [38], which indirectly confirms the positive effect of microwave heating on the promotion of catalyst activity. Finally, the influence of Re addition on the reduction of NiO species can also be perceived. It can be seen that after Re addition, the peak temperatures of α- and γ-type NiO roughly remain unchanged while the peak temperature of β-type NiO shifts to lower temperature, indicating the binding force between β-type NiO and Al2O3 support is weakened and more Ni active sites could be acquired under low temperature H2 pretreatment. Fig. 4B presents the H2-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts. It can be expressly seen that for all of the catalysts, there is a towery H2 desorption peak centered at ca. 275 °C and a tiny broad H2 desorption peak centered at 550 °C, respectively. The lower temperature peak is generally ascribed to the desorbed H2 from the exposed metallic Ni atoms on the outer surface, while the higher temperature peak can be attributed to the H2 adsorbed in the subsurface layers of Ni atoms and/or to the spillover H2 [39]. The adoption of microwave heating and the addition of Re promoter can change the H2 adsorption ability as can be deduced from the intensity and the peak temperature of H2 desorption peaks. The Ni reduction degree, H2 uptake and Ni dispersion of the catalysts calculated by H2-TPR and H2-TPD measurements are listed in Table 2 . Generally, catalysts prepared by microwave heating have larger Ni reduction degree and H2 uptake than those prepared by conventional heating, thus leading to higher Ni dispersion of the former. This convincingly suggests that microwave heating is beneficial to improve the Ni dispersion of the catalysts. However, the Ni dispersion of catalysts with Re addition is not necessarily improved, which is not similar with the Ni crystal size trend in Table 1. This is mainly due to that the Ni size determined by XRD in Table 1 represents the single Ni crystal while Ni dispersion measured by H2-TPD in Table 2 describes the Ni particle. The characterization of Ni particle dispersion should resort to other methods such as TEM, which will be discussed in the following Section 3.3.2. The contribution of Re is mainly reflected in the decrease of the reduction temperature for β-type NiO, which produces more active Ni sites that are important to improve the activity of the catalysts for CO methanation. 3.3 Evaluation of the catalytic activity 3.3.1 Effect of reaction temperature The CO conversion, CH4 selectivity and CO2 growth rate over different catalysts in the range of 300–400 °C were collected in Fig. 5 to investigate the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance. As revealed in Fig. 5A, the CO conversion for all of the catalysts exhibits nearly the same pattern. It firstly increases gradually with temperature from 300 to 350 °C and reaches the maximum value at 350 °C. When the reaction temperature increases from 350 to 400 °C, the CO conversion gradually decreases. Typically, the CO conversion for Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst at 350 °C is 82.7%, which is larger than the other five catalysts. The maximum value of CO conversion at 350 °C is in the order of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) > Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) > Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) > Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MF) > Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MF) > Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF), implying that microwave heating for preparing catalysts is in favor of increasing the CO conversion. Moreover, from the whole temperature range, the CO conversion for catalysts prepared by microwave heating is commonly larger than conventional heating prepared catalysts, possibly due to the larger dispersion of Ni nanoparticles and H2 adsorption capabilities for the former type of catalysts. In order to characterize the degree of methanation and WGS, the CH4 selectivity and CO2 growth rate are employed and profiled in Fig. 5B and C, respectively. For CH4 selectivity in Fig. 5B, all catalysts possess a maximum value at 350 °C, indicating 350 °C is the optimal operation temperature. Besides, the CH4 selectivity for Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst at 350 °C surpasses the other five catalysts, which demonstrates its satisfying catalytic performance in carbon conversion. The CH4 selectivity is enhanced for Re-promoted catalysts when compared with Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF) and Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV), mainly owing to the promotion effect of Re in CH4 selectivity. Interestingly, the CO2 growth rate in Fig. 5C maintains an upward momentum with temperature, implying that WGS is favored under high temperature. However, the CO conversion after 350 °C in Fig. 5A decreases with temperature which is contrary to the CO2 growth rate tendency in Fig. 5C. Combined with CH4 selectivity in Fig. 5B, it can be concluded that the methanation dominates WGS at range of 350–400 °C. It should be noted that the consumption of CO comes from two sides-methanation and WGS. From the perspective of CO utilization efficiency, the best scenario is high-output CH4 with low-output CO2. The changing tendency in Fig. 5 comprehensively shows that 350 °C is the best fitted reaction temperature for methanation coupling with WGS, which in this case the synergy effect between methanation and WGS performs well. 3.3.2 Characterization analysis after evaluation tests Fig. 6 shows the XRD patterns of the used catalysts after evaluation tests. As can be seen, the typical diffraction peaks ascribed to γ-Al2O3 support as well as Ni (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes could still be clearly observed, which briefly illustrates that the evaluation tests did not alter the fundamental chemical compositions of the catalysts. Through comparison, the XRD patterns of the used catalysts are basically the same as the patterns of reduced catalysts in Fig. 3B. The Ni crystal size of the used catalysts were also calculated and listed in Table 1. As it shows, the Ni crystal size of microwave heating prepared catalysts is still smaller than conventional heating prepared ones after the evaluation tests, which reveals the satisfying inhibition effect of microwave heating on Ni crystal growth during reaction. Furthermore, according to the results of many authors [40–42], carbon deposition is a rather common phenomenon during CO methanation and WGS reaction. However, the diffraction peaks attributed to deposited carbon are not exhibited in Fig. 6 but it cannot fully testify that there is no carbon deposition on the catalysts. As a matter fact, the TG analysis in Fig. 7 has demonstrated the existence of deposited carbon on the used catalysts. Thus, it can be concluded the deposited carbon is in the form of amorphous state, leading to its disappearance in the XRD patterns. The undesirable carbon deposition during methanation coupling with WGS is mainly from the following side reaction, which is also known as the Boudouard reaction. (8) 2 C O → C + C O 2 Δ H 0 = - 172 k J / m o l In order to investigate the deposited carbon species quantitatively, TG analysis was employed and the results of the measurement were all displayed in Fig. 7. The weight loss was calculated by the difference value between fresh and used catalysts [43]. As can be seen, the determined amount of deposited carbon on the catalysts vary among each other. The following order is obtained (ranked in the order of decreasing total carbon deposition):Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MF) (13.8%) > Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) (11.5%) > Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MF) (10.6%) > Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) (10.2%) > Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF) (6.9%) > Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) (1.7%). It can be clearly seen that Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) has the lowest amount of carbon deposition among all the catalysts, showing its superior anti-coking ability over other five catalysts. As is well known, low carbon deposition is one of the key factors to extend the lifetime of the catalyst. Thus, Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) shows its promising potential to work for a long period. The lifetime test of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) will be discussed in the following Section 3.6. However, the relatively low carbon deposition of Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF) catalyst cannot stand for its outstanding anti-coking ability but should attribute to its low catalytic activity as indicated in Fig. 5. Though it seems irregular judging from the sequence of carbon deposition amount, some characteristics could still be observed. Both Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) have fewer deposited carbon than their corresponding conventionally calcined catalysts, suggesting that microwave heating is beneficial to decrease the carbon deposition amount. In addition, the impregnation sequence of Re makes a difference. The step impregnation prepared Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MF) similarly have fewer deposited carbon species than co-impregnation prepared Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MF), which helpfully instructs us to use step impregnation method when preparing Re-promoted catalysts. Fig. 8 A and B show the TEM images of the reduced Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalysts, respectively. According to the exposed literature [44], the prominent dark regions in the TEM images correspond to Ni particles in the reduced catalysts, which seem to be evenly distributed on the support. Nevertheless, material contrast in bright field TEM is affected by various factors including but not limited to atomic density, thickness, and lattice alignment. As such, it is difficult to distinguish the Ni particles from Al2O3 support based on contrast alone. For this reason, the dark field TEM measurement was conducted and the results were presented in Fig. 8C and D. The insert surrounded by red rectangle refers to the dark field TEM images of reduced Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MF), respectively. As can be seen, the Ni particles form a sharp contrast with the dark background of Al2O3 support, which is due to the difference in electron adsorption ability stemming from material thickness and elements. In comparison with Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MF) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MF), Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) have smaller Ni particle size and more uniform distribution of Ni particles on the support. While simply comparing Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV), their difference in Ni dispersion is inconspicuous, even in 20 nm scale (Fig. S5). Such observations are consistent with the results in Table 2 and conforms that microwave heating is favorable to increase Ni dispersion while the addition of Re is not necessarily positive in enhancing Ni dispersion. Fig. 8E and F give the HRTEM (High Resolution TEM) images of the reduced Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalysts. Apart from the observed lattice spacing of ca. 0.203 nm attributed to Ni (111) plane, the MnO2 (300) plane of ca. 0.201 nm could also be perceived whose existence can be proven by Mn2p scan in XPS analysis of Fig. S6. Such planes are closely related to the active sites in the methanation coupling with WGS [45]. The absence of Re species in Fig. 8F may be on account of its lower content and veil from Al2O3 support when added by step impregnation. Fig. 8G and H display the TEM images of the spent Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalysts. The carbon whiskers are clearly shown in Fig. 8G and are more intense than in Fig. 8H. It therefore can be deduced that the amount of deposited carbon on the spent Ni-Mn/Al2O3 (MV) is much larger than on the spent Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV), which is in accordance with the TG results in Fig. 7 and further demonstrates the outstanding capability of suppressing carbon deposition of the latter catalyst. 3.4 Effect of Re promotion and its impregnation sequence To clarify the effect of Re promotion and its impregnation sequence, the XPS analysis of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) were investigated and the results were listed in Fig. 9 . The discussion of H2-TPR results in Section 3.2.3 has elucidated that the addition of Re could lower the reduction temperature of β-type NiO from the perspective of structural effect, which leads to more active Ni sites for methanation coupling with WGS. The XPS analysis provides us with the angle of electronic effect that will be helpful to comprehensively understand the promotion role of Re. As it shows in Fig. 9A, the Re4f XPS spectra of both as-prepared Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) can be fitted into two subpeaks: Re7+ (46.2 eV) and its satellite (49.2 eV). After reduction, the binding energy of Re7+ for Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) has shifted from 46.2 eV to 45.5 eV, which indicates a transformation of Re2O7 → ReO x (x < 7/2). Such transformation of Re valence causes an increased electron cloud density and the partially reduced ReO x is an electron donor which is able to patronize Ni atoms with electron transfer [46,47]. However, the binding energy of Re7+ for Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) after reduction is nearly not changed and shifts slightly from 46.2 eV to 46.1 eV. Its decreased value of binding energy of Re7+ is much smaller than that of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) (0.1 eV versus 0.7 eV), demonstrating the less electron transfer from ReO x to Ni atoms than Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV). In order to support the above theory, the XPS analysis of Ni2p for reduced Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) were measured and shown in Fig. 9B. As can be seen, the Ni2p peaks of reduced Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) can be fitted into two subpeaks: Ni2+ and Ni°, consistent with the above H2-TPR results that show there is coexistence of various states of Ni species (Ni2+ and Ni°). The formation of Ni2+ is probably due to the partial oxidation of surface metallic Ni during sample transfer before XPS test. After doping Re species, the binding energy of Ni0 for Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) shifts from typical 852.6 eV to lower value (852.1 and 852.5 eV, respectively), which implies that Re addition could improve the electron cloud density of Ni species by electron transfer. Moreover, Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) has lower binding energy of Ni2+ and Ni0 than Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV), attesting that the impregnation sequence would inflict influence on the degree of increased electron cloud density and obviously the electron cloud density for the former catalyst is larger than the latter. According to Wang [48] and Lu [42,49], increased electron cloud density of Ni atoms by electron transfer from donors is beneficial to weaken the CO valence bond, which is crucial in the process of methanation and water gas shift. In consequence, the CO turnover frequency of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) should be theoretically higher than Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV). In fact, from the experimental results shown in Fig. 9C, the CO turnover frequency of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) is indeed larger than Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) from a wide range of H2/CO ratio 0.6–1.0. Finally, the XPS analysis of survey scan for spent Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) and Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) are shown in Fig. 9D. Besides for the chemical elements (Al, O, Mn, Ni and Re) contained in the both of the spent catalysts, the deposited carbon was also detected and the peak intensity of C1s for spent Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) is much shorter than the used Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV), testifying that the former catalyst has a better ability of suppressing carbon deposition and is in line with the above TG and TEM results. 3.5 Mechanism of Re promotion Based on the results and discussions above, for the Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst, a schematic depicting the mechanism of Re promotion was shown in Fig. 10 . Since Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) is prepared by step impregnation method, the Re precursors (NH4ReO4) first enter into the pore channels of the γ-Al2O3 support and subsequently are adsorbed by affluent internal surface. Through microwave heating Re precursors are transformed into Re2O7 and further reduced into ReO x species, which are fixed inside the support. To some extent, such chemical combination of ReO x promoter and γ-Al2O3 forms a type of composite support with unique physic-chemical properties, which has huge impact on NiO species/Ni atoms as discussed in Sections 3.2.3 and 3.4. The active Ni atoms and second component MnO2, which serve as active sites for methanation coupling with WGS, are supported after the impregnation of Re and are highly dispersed by microwave heating. Because of the existence of ReO x , the active Ni atoms are more easily obtained due to the decreased reduction temperature of β-type NiO. When the reactants including CO, H2 and H2O contact with the surface of the support, the methanation reaction and water gas shift would be enhanced for the following reason: (1) increased amount of active Ni atoms leading to more exposed active Ni sites as proven by H2-TPD measurement, (2) augmented Ni electron cloud density which is favorable for the breakage of CO valence bond and promotes the initiation of the first step in elementary reaction. Though the co-impregnation prepared Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) is also heated by microwave and has comparable Ni dispersion and H2 uptake with Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV), its electronic effect is less intense than Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV), leading to its unsatisfying catalytic performance. This may be on account of the difference in Re impregnation sequence. As reflected in Fig. 11 , the EDS mapping shows the difference of Re position in the catalysts. The Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) in Fig. 11A shows that Re locates in the catalyst with high dispersion because it is firstly impregnated before Ni and Mn. This provides prerequisite condition for the formation of ReO x -Al2O3 composite support as discussed above. While for Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV), the co-impregnation of Ni, Mn and Re will cause competition among each other when adsorbed in the internal surface of the support, which might result in the interruption during the formation of ReO x -Al2O3 composite support. As shown in Fig. 11B, the Re species with low content (1 wt.%) are generally situated in the shallow surface of the catalyst and there is little Re in the center, which implies that the co-impregnation of Ni, Mn and Re limits the Re species entering into deep layers of the support. Compared with Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV), such non uniform distribution of Re can hardly form ReO x -Al2O3 composite support, which induces the discrepancy in the degree of electron transfer from Re to Ni atoms. The lack of ReO x -Al2O3 composite support in Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) is also responsible for the larger deposited carbon amount than Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV). 3.6 Lifetime test Judging from the above discussions, it can be cautiously concluded that Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) has superior catalytic performance for methanation coupling with WGS over other catalysts, not only because of its highly dispersed Ni species from microwave heating but also due to the structural as well as electronic promotion effect of Re addition. From the broad view of commercial manufacturing and industrial application, developing catalysts with long life is one of the critical factors when constructing a reaction system. As a result, the lifetime test of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) at 350 °C, H2/CO = 0.8 and H2O/CO = 1 was conducted and the results are shown in Fig. 12 . It can be seen that the prepared Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) showed a stable performance during the 110-h lifetime test and the content of combustible components (CH4, H2 and CO) in the outlet gas fluctuates over the average value (15.41, 23.06 and 13.76%, respectively) without particularly large float, suggesting its high and practical potential in utilization as a bifunctional catalyst for methanation coupling with WGS under low H2/CO conditions. Besides, the changing trend of lower heating value with reaction time is also displayed in Fig. 12 and it is clearly shown that the lower heating value changes little with a mean value of 9.71 MJ/Nm3, which could be further enlarged to reach 10 MJ/Nm3 after gas upgrading unit in our designed process flow to meet the demand of heating value. The most widely used method in gas upgrading unit is partial removal of CO2 by various technologies such as water scrubbing, physical and chemical scrubbing, membrane adsorption and pressure swing adsorption (PSA) [50], which is quite mature in industry. Thus, it will not be discussed in depth. Fig. 13 presents the surface morphology of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) before and after the lifetime test. As can be seen, both samples show typical scanning images of well-dispersed Ni species through magnification into 10 μm scale. It seems that the Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst is structurally stable without collapse or rupture and the Ni crystal does not undergo serious sintering, which can be further confirmed by the slight decrease of specific area (−9.6%) and minor increase of Ni size (+4.8 nm) in Table S1. 4 Conclusions Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts prepared by microwave heating were investigated and tested for partial methanation coupling with WGS of low H2/CO biomass gas into urban gas. The catalysts were further characterized by various analytical measurements including N2 isothermal adsorption, ICP, XRD, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, SEM, TEM and XPS. The comprehensive results of the characterization analysis, performance tests and lifetime test showed that: (1) Microwave heating applied in the preparation process of catalysts is beneficial to improve the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles, which enhances the catalytic activity for CO methanation coupling with WGS. (2) The contribution of Re promoter lies in the both structural and electronic aspects. The structural effect could be represented by the lowered reduction temperature of β-type NiO (a type of NiO that has medium strong interaction with γ-Al2O3 support), which facilitates the exposed active Ni atoms for reaction. The electronic effect could be reflected by the decreased Ni2p binding energy, which is caused by the electron transfer from ReO x species to Ni atoms. Such increased electron cloud density of Ni atoms is favorable for breakage of CO valence bond. (3) The sequence of Re impregnation has influence on the catalytic performance. Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) prepared by step impregnation method generally performs better than Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) prepared by co-impregnation method, owing to the formation of ReO x -Al2O3 composite support, which is also conducive in suppressing carbon deposition. (4) The average lower heating value of low H2/CO biomass gas catalyzed by Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) is 9.71 MJ/Nm3 and will be further extended over 10 MJ/Nm3 through upgrading unit, which is eligible as urban gas for downstream users. The 110-h lifetime test demonstrates the industrial potential of Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) in the future urban gas production from low H2/CO biomass gas. coredata.dc:description: Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts were prepared by microwave and conventional heating separately, and tested for partial methanation coupling with water gas shift (WGS) of simulated biomass gas in a fixed bed reactor. A series of characterization techniques including N2 isothermal adsorption, XRD, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, SEM, TEM and XPS were employed to examine the physico-chemical properties of the catalysts. With the reaction condition of 350 °C, H2/CO = 0.8 and H2O/CO = 1, 82.6% CO conversion, 70.0% CH4 selectivity and 82.8% CO2 growth rate were obtained on the Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst, which indicated its excellent synergetic effect on partial methanation coupling with WGS. According to the characterization results, it was found that microwave heating was beneficial to increase the dispersion of Ni species in comparison with conventional heating and the addition of Re promoter elevated the catalytic performance from both structural and electronic aspects, which was proven by the lowered reduction temperature of β-type NiO and the intensified electron cloud density of active Ni atoms, respectively. In addition, the sequence of Re impregnation also had impact on the catalytic performance. Step impregnation prepared Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) exhibited larger turnover frequency (TOF) than co-impregnation prepared Ni-Mn-Re/Al2O3 (MV) in the H2/CO range of 0.6–1.0, owing to the larger electron cloud density and better anti-coking ability of the former catalyst. The 110-h lifetime test further demonstrated the potential of stable Ni-Mn/Re-Al2O3 (MV) catalyst in industrial application.
coredata.dc:title: Re-promoted Ni-Mn bifunctional catalysts prepared by microwave heating for partial methanation coupling with water gas shift under low H2/CO conditions
